groups:concept.deftn: the nature, category, function or aggregation of resource content with an emphasis on how the resource may be used in the classroom, professional development or in an informal educational setting

outline.groups:deftn: an audio recording of a book in print
the audio component (only) of a broadcast presented on or captured digitally from the web (e.g. podcast, newscast, speech, interviews)
an audio recording of a speech or classroom instruction
a recording of vocal, instrumental or mechanical sounds having rhythm, melody or harmony
recorded historical information obtained in interviews concerning personal experiences and recollections
a recording of a newscast, talk show or other oral presentation originally generated via the radio
recorded auditory material (e.g. natural world, mechanical, noise, tones)
data measurements generated when the measuring instrument and the medium to be measured are in direct contact
data generated by equations, computer models and numerical simulations
data measurements generated when the measuring instrument and the medium to be measured are not in direct contact

materials that are designed to measure student learning (exams, questionnaires, quizzes) or to support teacher design or development of such materials (rubrics). Materials that support existing assessments (answer keys). Materials that relate to the philosophy of assessment (articles about performance and authentic assessment, for example).
an intensive analysis of an individual unit (as a person or community) stressing developmental factors in relation to environment or a scientific study of a specific location or region

a classroom-based task or exercise, often part of a lesson plan or other larger unit of instruction, that helps student develop particular skills, knowledge, or habits of mind. Usually, activity goals and outcomes are specific.

a computer-based task or exercise, often part of a lesson plan or other larger unit of instruction, that helps students develop particular skills, knowledge, or habits of mind. Usually, activity goals and outcomes are specific (e.g. Mountain Simulation: Assignment).

a sequence of instructional units done over a semester or quarter that are designed by teachers, faculty, or a group of instructors to significantly advance student skills, knowledge, and habits of mind in a particular discipline and to help students meet specified requirements as set forth in a curricula or district or state policy (e.g. Introduction to the Atmosphere)

a program of study. Examples include academic standards, (the knowledge, skills and habits of mind students are expected to acquire in particular grade levels or clusters of grade levels) and the units of instruction, often with sample lesson plans, illustrative student activities, and essential and supplementary resources that can help students reach standards. Curricula are often designed at the state or school district level, but can also apply to a program of study required for a particular university or college-issued degree.
a field-based task or exercise, often part of a lesson plan or other larger unit of instruction, to help student develop particular or habits of mind. Usually, the goals and outcomes are specific.
directions or suggestions for learning experiences outside of the classroom, usually off-site, either general or specific to a particular location
supporting material for teachers regarding the use of learning materials with respect to learning objectives, classroom management, materials and assessment

a laboratory-based task or exercise, often part of a lesson plan or other larger unit of instruction, to help students develop particular skills, knowledge, or habits of mind; usually, the goals and outcomes are specific

a plan for helping students learn a particular set of skills, knowledge or habits of mind; often includes student activities as well as teaching ideas, instructional materials, and other resources; is shorter in duration than and often a part of a unit or module
a sequence of lesson plans designed to teach a set of skills, knowledge and habits of mind (e.g. Understanding the Water Cycle)
a formal representation of ideas that is illustrated to others either visually or by the act of doing (e.g. PowerPoint slides)
a series of tasks or questions posed to the student, as in a homework or other assignment
activities organized around a particular academic topic where goals and outcomes are generally broad in nature and interactions with others often occur
general material describing a course or unit of study, includes outlines and table of contents
a resource that provides guided, practical information about a specific subject or task
a series of on-line visual and text-based resources that mimic a field trip experience in an electronic setting
a reference to a non-web-based entity like a book, CD-ROM or rock sample which does not have an URL at which the object can be ordered
generally a URL that includes .com or .biz as part of the website address
generally a URL that includes .edu as part of the website address
generally a URL that includes .gov as part of the website address
generally a URL that includes .org or .museum as part of the website address
a site where one can submit questions for personal response to either an individual or group of people who have specific expertise in the area of interest

a site that offers links to other sites organized around a topic or topics. The linked to sites are hosted by unrelated organizations. This is different than portal where the linked to sites are hosted by a single or related organizations.
an interface where a group of individuals can engage in text-based talk about a particular subject; may or may not be synchronous (e.g. blogs)
an email based communication that are usually topic-focused and distributed to a member-based group of individuals via a single email address
interface whereby individuals can post information, requests or ideas for view by others
mechanism by which the Internet or some sub-component is searched based on a specific query entered by the user (more extensive than Search this Site)
a condensed version of a larger piece of work, outlining the major points and conclusions
a long written composition (includes literature, technical documentation and guides, excluding field and instructor guides)
a collection of specialized terms and their meanings

a list (as of bibliographical information or citations to a body of literature) arranged usually in alphabetical order of some specified datum (as author, subject, or keyword); a list often with descriptive or critical notes of writings relating to a particular subject, period, or author; a list of works written by an author or printed by a publishing house; the works or a list of the works referred to in a text or consulted by the author in its production
a writing that shares ideas or research results which appear in a periodical publication that is often peer-reviewed and of an academic nature
a publication that is produced on some predictable schedule, such as weekly, monthly or annually
a document containing statements or a series of steps to accomplish something
a collection of papers or abstracts presented at a specific meeting or event
a formal document that outlines a specific project, recommendation, plan or idea

a work containing useful facts or information (e.g. user's guides, technical manuals). A student might consult this during independent research. It does not have a guided component. It may comprise hyperlinked pages but a specific path through it is not designated.
a detailed account or statement outlining the results or events of a meeting, endeavor, activity or study (e.g. review, evaluation)
scholarly work for an academic degree
a placeholder term when an appropriate resource type value has yet to be determined
a tool for mathematical manipulations (e.g. Celsius to Fahrenheit, satellite tracker)
computer instructions that allows for the enhancement of a resource; it generally does not stand alone (e.g. numerical models, applets)

a tool that allows access, interactions with or the ability to run resources; it does not enhance another piece of software rather it stands alone, (e.g. tools to look at and analyze data or create learning materials)
a visual not generated from data and not meant to illustrate a scientific concept or process (e.g. artistic drawing, animations, clip art, virtual tours)

a 2-D representation of physical data at a single point in time or space that illustrate fairly static physical features (e.g. topographic, soil, road or bedrock maps, etc.). For weather or forecast maps, use scientific visualization.
an image that has been taken with a camera and is available either online or offline
imagery generated from measuring devices that are not in direct contact with the medium they are measuring (e.g. radar or satellite imagery)
still or animated images, not based directly on data, that illustrate scientific concepts or processes through diagrams, graphs, figures or virtual reality (e.g. The Wilson Cycle)
dynamic or static visuals generated from physical data or model output (e.g. simulations, animations, weather forecast maps or streamflow maps)
animated images for use on a computer or television screen (e.g. clips, interviews, lectures, movies, etc.)
a predominantly image related broadcast or podcast presented on or captured from the Internet (may include audio)
